description: CLAYTON, Mo. Today marks one week since the death of George Floyd who died while in police custody in Minneapolis. He said that Black Lives Matter became a national rallying cry after a police officer shot and killed Michael Brown in Ferguson. The protests downtown, in Clayton and in Ferguson have been a peaceful gathering of solidarity over the weekend.
text:
CLAYTON, Mo.  Today marks one week since the death of George Floyd who died
while in police custody in Minneapolis. There have been protests across our
county and in St. Louis for several days.

St. Louis County Executive Sam Page addressed the demonstrations during a
weekly press conference about the economic and health impacts of COVID-19. He
said that Black Lives Matter became a national rallying cry after a police
officer shot and killed Michael Brown in Ferguson. The nation is still
struggling with inequality and three words in the Pledge of Allegiance,
"Justice for All."

Page said that the virus is disproportionately affecting African-American
communities. The administration is working on helping those in need. They are
working to distribute $173 million in federal CARES Act grants to help fight
the virus in all areas of the county. He also announced that all businesses
may reopen by the end of the month.

The protests downtown, in Clayton and in Ferguson have been a peaceful
gathering of solidarity over the weekend. But as the sun goes down things turn
violent.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles imposed a curfew at 8:00 pm Sunday. Protesters
were still there after 9:00 pm. Some threw items at officers. One officer was
hit by a rock.

Police declared the gathering an "unlawful assembly". Officers ordered the
group to leave. Someone threw a large firework at officers and one officer was
injured.

Officers then used tear gas to disperse the crowd. Police say there were also
shots fired at officers. A police vehicle and some businesses were damaged.
Officers made six arrests.

keywords.text: St. Louis County Executive Sam Page

title: 'Justice for All' County Executive reflects on protests during the pandemic
html:
CLAYTON, Mo. – Today marks one week since the death of George Floyd who died while in police custody in Minneapolis. There have been protests across our county and in St. Louis for several days.

St. Louis County Executive Sam Page addressed the demonstrations during a weekly press conference about the economic and health impacts of COVID-19. He said that Black Lives Matter became a national rallying cry after a police officer shot and killed Michael Brown in Ferguson. The nation is still struggling with inequality and three words in the Pledge of Allegiance, "Justice for All."

Page said that the virus is disproportionately affecting African-American communities. The administration is working on helping those in need. They are working to distribute $173 million in federal CARES Act grants to help fight the virus in all areas of the county. He also announced that all businesses may reopen by the end of the month.

The protests downtown, in Clayton and in Ferguson have been a peaceful gathering of solidarity over the weekend. But as the sun goes down things turn violent.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles imposed a curfew at 8:00 pm Sunday. Protesters were still there after 9:00 pm. Some threw items at officers. One officer was hit by a rock.

Police declared the gathering an "unlawful assembly". Officers ordered the group to leave. Someone threw a large firework at officers and one officer was injured.

Officers then used tear gas to disperse the crowd. Police say there were also shots fired at officers. A police vehicle and some businesses were damaged. Officers made six arrests.
